evidence.text: This is a civil action alleging that carcinogenic chloroprene emissions from Defendant Denka Performance Elastomer, LLC’s (“Denka’s”) neoprene manufacturing operations at the Pontchartrain Works Site in St. John the Baptist Parish, Louisiana (the “Facility”) present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and welfare.

extracted.value: The case is a civil action alleging carcinogenic chloroprene emissions from Denka's neoprene manufacturing operations at the Pontchartrain Works Site in St. John the Baptist Parish, Louisiana (Facility).

evidence.text: Denka’s neoprene manufacturing operations at the Facility are located in St. John the Baptist Parish at 586 Highway 44, LaPlace, Louisiana, 70068.

extracted.value: Facility address: 586 Highway 44, LaPlace, Louisiana, 70068.

evidence.text: Denka began manufacturing neoprene at the Facility on approximately November 1, 2015.

extracted.value: Denka began manufacturing neoprene at the Facility on approximately November 1, 2015.

evidence.text: Denka purchased the neoprene manufacturing operations at the Facility in 2014 from E.I. DuPont de Nemours and Company.

extracted.value: Denka purchased the neoprene manufacturing operations at the Facility in 2014 from E.I. DuPont de Nemours and Company.

evidence.text: Pursuant to a January 6, 2017 Administrative Order on Consent issued by the Louisiana DEQ, Denka agreed to reduce chloroprene emissions from its neoprene manufacturing operations.

extracted.value: The EPA issued an administrative order on consent on January 6, 2017 to reduce chloroprene emissions.

evidence.text: Denka upgraded equipment and installed emission control devices, including a Regenerative Thermal Oxidizer which became fully operational in March of 2018.

extracted.value: Denka installed a Regenerative Thermal Oxidizer (RTO) that became fully operational in March 2018.

evidence.text: Despite these emission reductions, Denka continues to emit approximately 18 tons of chloroprene each year.

extracted.value: Despite RTO, Denka continues to emit approximately 18 tons of chloroprene each year.

evidence.text: EPA and Denka monitoring data from 2016 show average chloroprene concentrations in the communities surrounding the Facility that are multiples greater than 0.2 µg/m3.

extracted.value: EPA and Denka monitoring data from 2016 show average chloroprene concentrations in the communities surrounding the Facility that are multiples greater than 0.2 µg/m3.

evidence.text: In 2010, the EPA IRIS program published its peer‑reviewed assessment of chloroprene (the “2010 IRIS Assessment”). In the 2010 IRIS Assessment, the EPA concluded that chloroprene is “likely to be carcinogenic to humans” and determined that it acts through a mutagenic mode of action.

extracted.value: EPA IRIS assessment (2010) concluded chloroprene is likely carcinogenic to humans.

evidence.text: In the 2010 IRIS Assessment, the EPA also quantified the cancer risks associated with long‑term chronic inhalation exposure to chloroprene. Breathing is the primary pathway… The EPA’s 2010 IRIS Assessment establishes 0.2 µg/m3 as the average concentration of chloroprene that a person may breathe over a 70‑year lifetime without being expected to exceed a 1‑in‑10,000 risk of contracting chloroprene‑linked cancers.

extracted.value: EPA 2010 IRIS established 0.2 µg/m3 as the average concentration that does not exceed a 1‑in‑10,000 lifetime excess cancer risk.

evidence.text: 1.2 µg/m3 is the average chloroprene concentration a child may regularly breathe from birth to their second birthday without being expected to exceed a 1‑in‑10,000 lifetime risk of contracting chloroprene‑related cancers.

extracted.value: EPA 2010 IRIS established 1.2 µg/m3 as the average concentration a child may breathe from birth to second birthday without exceeding a 1‑in‑10,000 lifetime risk.

evidence.text: Denka’s monitoring sites from April 2018 through January 2023 averaged 1.46 µg/m3— more than 7 times higher than 0.2 µg/m3.

extracted.value: Denka’s emissions result in average chloroprene concentration across all Denka sampling sites from April 2018 through January 2023 of approximately 1.46 µg/m3.

evidence.text: The worst of Denka’s sampling locations (the Western monitor, which is closest to the residential neighborhood west of the Facility) showed average concentrations of 2.89 µg/m3, more than 14 times higher than 0.2 µg/m3.

extracted.value: Worst Denka monitor (Western) average 2.89 µg/m3.

evidence.text: The EPA’s monitoring sites, starting in April 2018, show that the average chloroprene concentration across all the EPA’s sampling sites from April 2018 through September 2020 was 1.43 µg/m3—7 times higher than 0.2 µg/m3.

extracted.value: EPA monitoring across all sites April 2018–September 2020 average 1.43 µg/m3.

evidence.text: The worst of EPA’s sampling locations (the Chad Baker site, in the residential neighborhood west of the Facility) showed average concentrations of 2.22 µg/m3, more than 11 times higher than 0.2 µg/m3.

extracted.value: Worst EPA monitor (Chad Baker) average 2.22 µg/m3.

evidence.text: According to United States census data, between approximately 15,000 to 17,000 people live within two‑and‑a‑half miles of Denka’s Facility.

extracted.value: Population within 2.5 miles: approximately 15,000 to 17,000 people.

evidence.text: Over 20% of that population (roughly 3,000‑4,000) is under the age of 18.

extracted.value: About 20% of that population (roughly 3,000‑4,000) is under age 18.

evidence.text: Of those 3,000‑4,000 young people, approximately 800‑1,000 are young children under the age of 5.

extracted.value: Approximately 800‑1,000 young children under age 5 reside in the area.

evidence.text: The EPA’s 2010 IRIS Assessment establishes 0.2 µg/m3 as the average concentration of chloroprene that a person may breathe over a 70‑year lifetime without being expected to exceed a 1‑in‑10,000 risk of contracting chloroprene‑linked cancers. 1.2 µg/m3 is the average chloroprene concentration a child may regularly breathe from birth to their second birthday without being expected to exceed a 1‑in‑10,000 lifetime risk of contracting chloroprene‑related cancers.

extracted.value: Risk estimates: 1‑in‑10,000 lifetime excess cancer risk at 0.2 µg/m3; 1.2 µg/m3 for children.

evidence.text: The Ground Lease has an effective date of approximately October 30, 2015 and lasts for a 99‑year term.

extracted.value: Ground Lease effective date: approximately October 30, 2015; term 99 years.

evidence.text: Denka’s neoprene manufacturing operations consist primarily of three chemical manufacturing process units: the Chloroprene Unit, the Neoprene Unit, and the HCl Recovery Unit.

extracted.value: Denka’s Neoprene manufacturing consists of three units: Chloroprene Unit, Neoprene Unit, HCl Recovery Unit.

evidence.text: Denka is a joint venture between majority owner Denka Company Limited and minority owner Mitsui & Co. Ltd., both of which are Japanese companies.

extracted.value: Denka is a joint venture between majority owner Denka Company Limited and minority owner Mitsui & Co. Ltd.

evidence.text: Denka is incorporated in Delaware.

extracted.value: Denka is incorporated in Delaware.

evidence.text: DuPont Specialty Products owns the land at the Pontchartrain Works Site on which Denka’s neoprene manufacturing operations are located.

extracted.value: DuPont Specialty Products owns the land at the Pontchartrain Works Site and is landlord.

evidence.text: Denka may need DuPont Specialty Products’ permission or cooperation to comply with the Court’s orders… The Ground Lease requires Denka to obtain DuPont Specialty Products’ consent before undertaking certain construction activities or equipment modifications.

extracted.value: Denka may need DuPont’s consent to undertake certain construction activities under Ground Lease.
